awd_titl_txt: TC: Medium: From Statistics to Circuits: Foundations for Future On-chip Fingerprints
awd_abstract_narration: In a world where everybody and everything is electronically connected, identity is essential to support trustworthy transactions. This project investigates novel techniques to design and implement on-chip fingerprints. Such fingerprints establish the hardware identity of an electronic system. The on-chip fingerprints are based on the existing, small and random manufacturing variations of electronic chips. Using a cross-disciplinary approach that combines recent advances in the field of statistics with those in circuit design, this project develops on-chip fingerprint structures that are optimized for stability, implementation cost, and security. Stable on-chip fingerprints are maximally sensitive to random manufacturing variations, and minimally sensitive to other environmental factors such as temperature, voltage, noise, and aging. Low-cost on-chip fingerprints are obtained by using statistical, architectural, and circuit-level techniques that maximize the amount of extracted entropy. Secure on-chip fingerprints are resistant against common attacks such as reverse engineering and model building. Thanks to its cross-disciplinary character, this project establishes a much-needed link between advanced statistical analysis and deep-submicron design for the purpose of circuit identification. This leads to better PUF designs, applicable across a wider range of applications: secure passports, anti-counterfeiting schemes, and security and trust at the endpoints. The project includes strong integration of research and education. For pre-college and entering freshman students, the project offers an introduction to trusted hardware, in the context of existing on-campus programs that involve minorities in engineering. For graduate students, the project offers a team-taught course, shared between the electrical engineering department and the statistics department.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we studied techniques to extract stable fingerprints from electronic circuits. These fingerprints, also called PUF (Physical Unclonable Functions), find a wide range of applications in the context of identification of objects and generation of object-unique codes. This need, in turn, is driven by the myriad of electronic objects that connect to the Internet, and that somehow need to be identified or authenticated. PUF technology allows to achieve this objective in a simple and straightforward fashion.

The project was performed as a collaboration between a statistician, a computer architect, and a circuit designer. This team was therefore able to consider all aspects of fingerprint identifier design. Fingerprints are created on the basis of small variations occurring during the manufacturing of circuits. Analyzing those variations from a statistical perspective requires a statistician; integrating those circuits in a form that is compatible with a computer architecture requires a computer architect; and designing the circuits themselves for maximum quality requires a circuit designer.

During the project, several innovations have been made, including low-power optimization for circuit fingerprints, studying of aging effects, large-scale statistical analysis of prototype fingerprint designs, and the development of novel techniques that increase the amount of information bits extracted per fingerprint.

This project supported and trained 9 students, including one undergraduate researcher and eight graduate researchers. These students have now joined the US industry as an electronics engineer or as a data analyst. The results of the project have also been published in numerous conference - and journal articles, as well as in conference tutorials. A unique artifact maintained by this project is a PUF circuit database of measurements, which is used by many research groups worldwide in PUF research.

By the ending of the project, in 2015, PUF has become a key research domain in hardware security. In this project, which started in 2011, we have had the unique opportunity to contribute to this important and vibrant research area.
